Chapter 47, Part 2: The Assembly of Bodhisattva RatnacÅ«á¸a
The Buddha told the son of a great clan:
What are the five pure faculties of a bodhisattva?
Not grasping at any dharmas while cultivating the meaning of the Way is the faculty of faith.
Vowing to reach the other shore without needing to be guided by others is the faculty of zeal.
Not abandoning the Way's intention for the sake of all is the faculty of intention.
Grasping great compassion and wishing to save those in danger and distress is the faculty of concentration.
If one can receive and cultivate all dharmas while practicing tranquility, this is the faculty of wisdom.
Moreover, son of a great clan!
Deeply believing in all the Buddhadharmas and following the traces of the Way is the faculty of faith.
Respectfully upholding the Buddhadharmas without ever becoming weary is the faculty of zeal.
Remembering the Buddhadharmas and keeping the holy meaning in mind without ever forgetting or abandoning it is the faculty of intention.
Cultivating the Buddha's concentration without ever being lax or negligent is the faculty of concentration.
The root of wisdom is to be able to eliminate all sentient beings' doubts and bonds without any thought of wishing for anything.
Moreover, aspiring for the Buddha's path without harboring hesitation is the root of faith.ğŸ”½To be of gentle nature and to cultivate diligence without retreating is the root of diligence.
To encourage and assist in the growth of meritorious roots without loss is the root of intention.
Equally emitting light to illuminate sentient beings and rescuing them from confusion is the root of concentration.
Discerning the fundamental nature of all people and expounding the Dharma for them is the root of wisdom.
Transcending all obstructions without attachment is the root of faith.
Resolving sentient beings' bonds and causing them to be free from all ties is the root of diligence.
The practice of one's own commitment without attachment, walking alone in the three realms with a unique distinction, is the root of intention.
Knowing the causes and conditions of all obstructions is the root of concentration.
Comprehending all attachments and wisdom that is not reached is the root of wisdom.
Furthermore, to follow what is to be done without being confused is the faculty of faith.
To transform people without confusion, to abandon non-dharmas, to always maintain joy, is the faculty of zeal.

To always practice purity according to the Dharma teachings, to not be confused by the various defilements, to not forget the meaning of the Way and to cultivate it more and more each day, is the faculty of mindfulness.
To have a pure mind, to practice equally, and to attain liberation through the correct reception of the wisdom of the sages, is the faculty of concentration.
If one is unobstructed in the Dharma realm, if one abandons non-dharmas and abides in the clear understanding of the Dharma, this is the faculty of wisdom.
To eliminate all non-virtuous roots and to cultivate various merits is the faculty of faith.
To follow all virtuous roots and to follow the scriptures is the faculty of zeal.
To accumulate various virtues without violating the Dharma is the faculty of mindfulness.
To be joyful in concentrated thought, to not crave for pleasure and comfort, and to discern the roots of virtue of sentient beings is the faculty of concentration.
Upholding various wholesome practices and cultivating the path of the Dharma according to skillful means is the faculty of wisdom.

Moreover, with faith one diligently abandons laziness, the mind has nothing to seek and nothing to forget, one protects concentration and prevents confusion, and one upholds wisdom to enlighten the ignorant.
Furthermore, one who practices faith abandons wrong teachings, one who practices diligence abandons self, and the mind focused on the body is free from greed.
By being able to practice concentration, one severs the net of the sixty-two views.
The one with wisdom eliminates all attachments and affection.
This, son of noble family!
Is the pure practice of the five faculties cultivated by the bodhisattvas.
The Buddha told the son of noble family:
What is meant by the bodhisattvas' pure practice of the five powers?

If one considers establishing these five faculties, practices them without abandoning, conquers the four demons, does not regress from the vehicle of Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas, never retreats from the MahÄyÄna, eliminates various desires, defilements, and impurities, their vows are firm, their minds attain mastery, their aspirations are courageous, their bodies are healthy, strong, and powerful, their faculties are tranquil, and their faith is indestructible.
This, son of noble family!
Is called the power of faith.
What should not be done is not done, and one controls one's nature and makes it balanced and harmonious. This is the power of diligence.
What should be cultivated is all practiced, and one's intentions are strong. This is called the power of intention.
The path and deeds that have been created are never forgotten, and one transcends all. This is called the power of concentration.
One is not endangered by forms, sounds, smells, tastes, and smooth textures, and one transcends all doubts and the mind's dwelling on various bonds. This is called the power of wisdom.
Moreover, the power of faith means not accepting anything taught by others.
The power of diligence means to uphold what should be upheld without forgetting or abandoning it.
The power of intention means to attain dhÄraá¹‡Ä« and the intention of the unshared path.
The power of concentration means to expound the Dharma equally without partiality.
The power of wisdom means to resolve all doubts and untie the bonds of the net of afflictions of sentient beings.
Moreover, the power of faith means to be able to fully possess the power of sincere faith.
The power of diligence means to liberate those who are firm and strong and have not yet crossed over.
The power of intention means to fully possess the power of wisdom and insight that liberates.
The power of concentration means to fully possess the power of the will that is ultimate.
The power of wisdom means to fully possess the source of all practices.
Moreover, the power of faith means to be able to control the difficulties of stinginess, greed, and defilements.
The power of diligence means to be able to let go of all that one possesses.
The power of intention means to manifest the roots of virtue and encourage the mind of the path.
The power of concentration means to equally practice with an impartial mind and abandon all that is sought.
The power of wisdom is to cultivate all practices without ever expecting reward.
Moreover, the power of faith is to eliminate all the aggregates of broken precepts.
The power of diligence is to diligently cultivate precepts without ever violating them.
The power of intention is to be fully endowed with the mind of the Way and prevent it from leaking out.
The power of concentration is to be able to return to the land of gentleness and harmony.
The power of wisdom is to sever birth and death in all practices.
Moreover, the power of faith is to be free from disputes and the basis of anger.
The power of diligence is to be mindful of one's practices and diligently cultivate patience.
The power of intention is to be fully endowed with the practices of the Way and not violate the Dharma.
The power of concentration is to first control one's mind and prevent it from being negligent, and to protect all kinds of sentient beings.
The power of wisdom is to not conceive of self or the notion of a person.
Moreover, the power of faith is to abandon laziness and the defilements of dust and dirt.
The power of diligence is to transcend all causes and conditions and not be confused by evil things.
The power of intention is to cultivate the path and make it complete.
The power of concentration is to rest the body and be able to subdue demons.
The power of wisdom is to do everything without fail.
Moreover, the power of faith is to digest the defilements and practices of various heterodoxies.
The power of diligence is to gather sentient beings and enlighten them.
The power of intention is to always have a single aspiration and encourage them.
The power of concentration is to always practice tranquility and never be agitated.
The power of wisdom is to understand the Dharma practiced by all people.
Moreover, the power of faith is to abandon the defilements of various views and knowledge.
The power of diligence is to always diligently practice and seek extensive learning.
The power of intention is to contemplate and purify one's practice as appropriate.
The power of concentration means that the mind is unproduced and thus able to attain.
The power of wisdom means diligently studying and being capable of achieving accomplishment.
Moreover, the power of faith means always attaining sincerity and the seven kinds of wealth.
The power of diligence means clearly discerning and achieving the seven factors of enlightenment.
The power of intention means the mind is always composed and never confused.
The power of concentration means transcending the seven abodes of consciousness.
The power of wisdom means surpassing the eight kinds of wrongness without attachment.
Being indestructible and always pure is the power of faith.
Purely practicing without retreating, without purity or impurity, without suitability or unsuitability, is the power of diligence.
Purifying the mind and gathering the various factors of the path, without mind and without thought, is the power of intention.
Diligent practice of the mind in tranquility is correct meditation, which is the power of concentration.
If one can purify and not be confused by various views, and uphold the roots of virtue, this is the power of wisdom.
This is the case, son of noble family!
The five powers practiced by bodhisattvas are pure.
The Buddha said to the son of noble family:
What is meant by the purity of the bodhisattvas' seven factors of enlightenment?
Those who manifest the factor of enlightenment of intention attain mastery and the wisdom of the unshared path.
The factor of enlightenment of the Dharma observes what is practiced and follows the appropriate time without attachment.
The factor of enlightenment of vigor diligently practices and attains unobstructedness.
The factor of enlightenment of joy is the mind attaining non-attachment.
The factor of enlightenment of faith is the body and mind resting and attaining the ultimate.
The factor of enlightenment of concentration is being apart from the flavor of intention and attaining penetration.
The factor of enlightenment of contemplation is the completion of all the deeds that are undertaken.
Moreover, seeking the mind of the Way is also without attainment and without loss, which is the factor of enlightenment of intention.
If one protects the Dharma and diligently makes progress, this is the factor of enlightenment of the faculty of zeal.
If one teaches sentient beings without weariness, this is the factor of enlightenment of the faculty of vigor.
If one delights in the bliss of the Dharma and earnestly contemplates it, this is the factor of enlightenment of the faculty of joy.
If one transforms people and eliminates afflictions to establish them on the path, this is the factor of enlightenment of the faculty of trust.
If one abides in equanimity and the mind is not disturbed, this is the factor of enlightenment of the faculty of concentration.
If one is able to observe and practice the wisdom of sages and saints to establish the multitude of people, this is the factor of enlightenment of the faculty of contemplation.
If one is free from worry and thought like a lion, surpassing the vehicles of Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas, this is the factor of enlightenment of the faculty of intention.
If one understands that all dharmas are completely pure, this is the factor of enlightenment of the faculty of the Dharma.
If one's practice is pure and one guards body, speech, and mind without transgression, this is the factor of enlightenment of the faculty of vigor.
If one is pure and unattached, free from danger and harm, this is the factor of enlightenment of the faculty of joy.
If one cultivates and adorns one's practice, accomplishing what should be done, this is the factor of enlightenment of the faculty of trust.
Never conforming to the worldly dust, with equal appearance and form, this is the category of concentration and enlightenment.
Never dwelling in the practice of duality, free from drifting, always observing and protecting, rescuing sentient beings, this is the category of contemplation and enlightenment.
The Buddha told the son of a great clan:
Why is it called the category of enlightenment?

Clearly understanding all dharmas without fail, discerning and comprehending their direction, understanding their deportment and etiquette, and transforming sentient beings, diligently cultivating and widely practicing the meaning of the Way in their dwelling place, removing the bonds and entanglements, this is the category of mental enlightenment.
This is then the practice of the sages, not the practice of fools.

Speaking of the practice of the sages, it is not the practice of demons, nor the practice of those who are arrogant and self-important. The practice of the sages is not something that non-Buddhist practitioners can attain.
The practice of the sages does not involve the dharmas of form, sound, smell, taste, and touch.
The practice of the sages is to be free from the attachment of various thoughts and conditions.
The practice of the sages is to be free from the selection of places and directions, and from forgetfulness.
The practice of the sages is to be free from the actions of the mind, consciousness, and thoughts.
The practice of the sages is to be free from the knowledge and views of hearing, thinking, and knowing.
The practice of the sages is to be free from the thoughts and ideas of attaining nirvana.
The practice of the sages is to be free from all practices.
Cultivating the scriptures, being free from acceptance and rejection, recollection and non-recollection, and having no other thoughts, is the practice of the sages.

Not dwelling in any dharma, not longing for lofty places, is the practice of the sages.ğŸ”½Not being confused in any dharma, practicing the true meaning in accordance with it and causing each to attain its proper place, is the practice of the sages.
Never disputing in any dharma, living in harmony, is the practice of the sages.
Practicing all dharmas without the notion of dharmas, not losing the intention of the Way, this is the practice of the sages.
This son of a good family!
Cultivates the practice of the seven factors of enlightenment, which is pure and noble.
The Buddha said to the son of a good family:
What is meant by a bodhisattva cultivating the pure practice of the eightfold path?
The so-called eightfold path practitioner, first, is right view.
What is meant by right view?
If one is able to practice all dharmas, in the self and non-self, one does not dwell in the contemplation of emptiness.
Why is this?
Contemplating the self of the body, there is no difference, and one also does not dwell in the contemplation of the emptiness of the person of the body.
Why is this?
The body, the person, and emptiness are also equal.
One also does not dwell in the contemplation that the person, life, and emptiness are separate.
Why is this?
The person, life, and emptiness.
Contemplating the mind as equal, one also does not contemplate existence and birth and death, apart from the meaning of emptiness without beginning and end.
Why is this?
All the sufferings of birth, death, and the beginning and end, and what is seen as empty are all the same.
Do not dwell in the view of emptiness, cutting off the view of permanence, or the view of existence of self.
Why is it so?
Cutting off the view of permanence is also the same.
Do not think of the body or the emptiness that is observed, and do not dwell in this.
Why is it so?
The body, self, and emptiness are all the same.
Also do not dwell in seeing the Buddha, Dharma, and Saá¹…gha, or in the practice of observing emptiness.
Why is it so?
Seeing the Buddha, Dharma, and Saá¹…gha, and what is observed as empty are all the same.
O son of a great clan!
If there is a view of this and that, observing up to nirvÄá¹‡a, this is called the correct view of seeing the Buddha, Dharma, and Saá¹…gha. The wrong view does not depart from inversion.
If there is no thought of the various views, whether superior, middling, or inferior, this is called the correct view.
Why is it so?
Because observing them as equal, there is also no wrong.
What is considered seeing?
The seer should observe equality.
Seeing the dharmas of ordinary beings as lowly and the dharmas of those who study as lofty, such a view is a mistaken view.
Seeing the dharmas of ordinary beings as impure conduct that has not yet been eliminated, and the bodhisattva dharmas as being free from defilements, such a view is a mistaken view.
Seeing the dharmas of ordinary beings as having outflows and the dharmas of those who have nothing more to study as being without outflows, such a view is a mistaken view.
Seeing the dharmas of ordinary beings as seeking clothing and food, and the dharmas of pratyekabuddhas as not expecting offerings, such a view is a mistaken view.
Seeing those with small intentions as having aspirations, and the intentions of bodhisattvas as having no aspirations, such a view is a mistaken view.
Seeing the dharmas of ordinary beings as being lax, and the dharmas of bodhisattvas as being free from desires, such a view is a mistaken view.
Seeing the dharmas of ordinary beings as all having conditioned activities, and the true Dharma of the Buddha as being the unconditioned path, such a view is a mistaken view.
The Buddha told the son of a great clan:

If one is able to contemplate that the dharmas of ordinary beings and all dharmas are originally pure, and that the dharmas one studies are also originally pure, and to contemplate that all dharmas are naturally so, then this is right view.
The dharmas of ordinary beings and the dharmas one studies are also empty. To understand that the dharmas of study are empty is right view.
The dharmas of ordinary beings are equal to conditioned arising. To understand that the dharmas of the pratyekabuddhas are also equal to conditioned arising is right view.
The dharmas of ordinary beings are then tranquil and silent. The bodhisattva dharmas are also tranquil and pure. This is right view.
The dharmas of ordinary beings are not accomplished. The dharmas of the buddhas are also not ultimately real. This is right view.
Right view means that the mind does not enter duality and does not see duality. People are also non-dual and do not see a self. This is right view.

Those who do not have various views and do not take various views as different views have an impartial perspective. They do not think of any phenomena as superior, middling, or inferior. Not thinking of or seeing anything in all phenomena is right view.
Those with right view have no various views and see nothing. Seeing nothing is right view.
What can be observed has no form or color. Seeing all phenomena as having no form or color is right view.
This, son of noble family!
Observing all phenomena and understanding them in this way is called expounding the Dharma and Vinaya.
When this was said, the minds of five hundred bhiká¹£us were liberated from defilements.
The Buddha told Bodhisattva RatnacÅ«á¸a:

So-called right mindfulness eliminates all thoughts and is united with tranquility and stillness. Observing the virtues of wisdom and attaining the Dharma of tranquility, one clearly understands what is observed and sees all phenomena.
What is believed in by thoughts, what is called the Dharma,
and what is called non-Dharma?
Understanding that all dharmas are each different and do not associate with each other, by understanding this, one does not think of equality, let alone believe in heterodox paths.
In all thoughts, there is no thought or non-thought, and nothing more to think of, nothing to respond to or not respond to, this is right mindfulness.
The Buddha told the son of a great clan:
What is called right speech, what is spoken is not seeing one's own body, not seeing others, not attached to self and others, not endangering oneself or others, this is called right speech.

Moreover, right speech means equally understanding all dharmas, knowing that all dharmas lead to extinction, knowing that all dharmas return to the Dharma of sages and liberation, this is called right speech.

Practicing with a compassionate mind, adding pity and compassion, no difference between relatives and enemies, right speech is also empty, equally expounding all dharmas, signless, wishless, nothing to do, not born, not arising, the words of all dharmas are equal, all dharmas are impermanent, suffering, empty, and not the teaching of the body.

The correct speech is to say that all dharmas are without a person or life span, to explain all dharmas arise from the mind, and to get the results according to the seeds planted. Bodhisattvas equally show sentient beings the sutra Dharma and make them practice the Buddha's path.
Correct speech purity is to be protected by all Buddhas in the ten directions. This is correct speech.
The Buddha told the son of a great clan:

The so-called correct action is to digest all actions, never to create the foundations of the original actions again, to extinguish the suffering caused by cultivated actions, to make all constant actions stand in emptiness, not to engage in wrong actions, to be free from dust and defilements, and to be without impurity. This is called correct action.

If a bodhisattva understands this action and all dharmas, and does not create anything in the foundation of all goodness but cultivates virtuous practices, this is called non-action, which is to create action. It is the abode of emptiness and nothingness. This is called the bodhisattva's practice of the supreme path as correct action.
The Buddha told the son of a great clan:
What is called right livelihood is not to think of self or others. This is called right livelihood.
Those of right livelihood do not accumulate any afflictions.

The right livelihood of bodhisattvas is able to purify the dispositions of sentient beings. Having purified their dispositions, they do not think of themselves, nor do they have a lifespan or equality. It is for the sake of self, others, and the Dharma that they practice pure meaning. This is called right livelihood.

The Buddha told the son of a great clan:ğŸ”½What is called right effort is not to engage in non-dharma activities, and to not abandon the virtues that are created with skillful means and to be at ease without cowardice. To cultivate right practice and to be close to purity, this is called right effort.

Those of right effort do not engage in wrong effort. The skillful means they create are in accordance with their words. They do not think of dharmas as equal or unequal. There is no creation or non-creation, just as all dharmas abide. In accordance with their practice, they set up skillful means.

Calculating in this way, the Dharma of all Buddhas is also like this. As it is tranquil, using this as a skillful means, all dharmas are equal without distinction, and the practice is also equal. For all sentient beings, removing their wrong skillful means, then encouraging and assisting in all penetrating wisdom. This is the correct skillful means practiced by the bodhisattvas.
The Buddha told the son of a great clan:

What is called the correct mind means to recollect the Buddha's path, to contemplate giving, upholding precepts, patience, diligence, single-mindedness, wisdom, kindness, compassion, joy, and equanimity. This is called the correct mind.
To contemplate with sincerity, not listening to the defilements of all afflictions, not following the ways of MÄra.

What one contemplates, wherever one is born, does not fall into wrong views. Skillfully controlling one's mind and restraining one's thoughts, like a gatekeeper who knows when to close and open the gate.
Removing all unwholesome thoughts and ideas, not listening to wrong thoughts. This is called the correct mind.
Bodhisattvas, abiding in this right intention, do not attain fruition within this path of quiescence and cessation. This is the pure practice of right intention for bodhisattvas.
The Buddha told the son of a great clan:

The so-called right concentration of bodhisattvas follows the practices of the sages, knowing the truth of suffering, cutting off the seeds of the truth of accumulation, realizing the seeds of the truth of cessation, and upholding the seeds of the truth of the path. This is right concentration.
If they correctly receive it, they are equal to their own bodies and also equal to all dharmas.
Their own bodies are pure, and all dharmas are also pure. Their own bodies are empty, and all dharmas are also empty.
Those who can correctly receive concentration in this way enter into equality without falling into cessation. This is the pure practice of right concentration for bodhisattvas.

In the instant of arousing the mind, their practices are equal, and they are fully endowed with wisdom and all the sagely blessings of realizing all dharmas. This is the pure practice of right concentration for bodhisattvas.

When the Buddha spoke of this right and true enlightenment, 1,600 heavenly and human disciples who enjoyed the Lesser Vehicle and had already entered its teachings changed their minds and gave rise to the intention for unsurpassed perfect truth.
The Buddha said to the son of a great clan:
What is meant by a bodhisattva guarding the mind of enlightenment?

Nurturing the mind so that it does not arise, eliminating desire, anger, and delusion, and removing attachment to form, sensation, perception, formation, and consciousness, being unattached to the three realms, walking alone in the three realms, passing through the three gates of liberation to attain the three kinds of insight, seeing the past, present, and future without obstruction, liberating sentient beings and removing their defilements, just like the sun's illumination shining everywhere.

Skillfully using wisdom to manifest in accordance with the times, wandering in the three realms like a lotus in water, teaching and transforming all to give rise to the intention for enlightenment - this is the bodhisattva's practice of guarding the mind of the path to enlightenment with purity.
The Buddha said to RatnacÅ«á¸a:
What is meant by a bodhisattva attaining spiritual powers as a practice of purity?
Moreover, by perfecting five things, one attains penetrating vision.
What are the five?

Attaining the light called the heavenly eye, illuminating the ten directions, extinguishing all darkness and seeing all radiance, seeing all Buddhas who can transform and liberate many beings, this is called the heavenly eye.
Seeing from afar the ultimate destination of sentient beings and adorning their aspirations, this is called the heavenly eye.

Seeing all the forms, appearances, and kinds in the ten directions, whether good or bad, long or short, the heavenly eye is unobstructed. The mind is tranquil and its characteristics are unconditioned, surpassing all gods, dragons, spirits, gandharvas, Å›rÄvakas, and pratyekabuddhas, seeing their origins and reaching everywhere.
O son of a great clan!
In this way, one attains the five supernatural powers and the heavenly eye, which becomes the eye of a bodhisattva.
This is the purity of the bodhisattva's heavenly eye.
The Buddha told the son of a great clan:
Moreover, by accomplishing five things, one attains penetrating hearing and hears everything.
What are the five?

Hearing human sounds, also penetratingly hearing non-human sounds, also hearing the sounds of suffering in the hells, hungry ghosts, and animals, and also hearing the Dharma teachings of all Buddhas in the ten directions, and all the different languages and expressions in the ten directions, with millions of different sounds, all able to listen and understand.
These are the five things, the pure penetrating hearing of the spiritual powers of the bodhisattvas.
The Buddha told the son of a great clan:
Again, through five things, one knows the thoughts in people's minds.

What are the five?ğŸ”½One is able to completely know the thoughts of good and evil in the minds of the various heavens, people, hells, hungry ghosts, and animals, and the causes and conditions of their past, and whether they will receive a body in the future.

Knowing the thoughts that will go to the past, present, and future, and the place of certain return to deviant practices, one completely understands the thoughts of good and evil conduct in the minds of sentient beings.
Observing their minds, if they harbor greed, anger, or ignorance, he teaches the Dharma according to their past practices.
This is the bodhisattva's practice of knowing the pure thoughts of all beings.
The Buddha told the son of a great clan:
What is meant by the bodhisattva's knowledge of the pure supernormal knowledge of the past?
It means knowing the ancient world through the five [supernormal] abilities.
Those who experience lust, anger, and delusion naturally experience them without mature contemplation, only giving rise to this matter.

Moreover, understanding one's own body through countless lifetimes, one then focuses on giving, upholding precepts, being patient, diligently practicing, single-mindedly, and with wisdom, compassion, joy, and equanimity.ğŸ”½Relying on one's concentration, one attains this, and also from having attained it, one experiences one's self, contemplating the various characteristics of the mind.
Those characteristics and causes and conditions also arise from oneself and are naturally experienced, contemplating the mind and observing one's intentions.

Entering the gate of delusion, one naturally receives [the consequences]. Remembering and recognizing this, following one's form, retinue, power, fame, nobility, poverty, suffering, and happiness, one's own body naturally acts and receives these afflictions.
This is called the bodhisattva's knowledge of the pure supernormal cognition of the past mind.
The Buddha told the son of a great clan:
What is meant by the bodhisattva possessing the supernormal powers?
It is by means of five things that one attains the supernormal powers.
What are the five?

Demonstrating the supernormal power of the physical body, the supernormal power of the spiritual consciousness and sounds, the supernormal power of the activities of the mind, and the supernormal power of pervading everywhere.
The supernormal power of distinguishing the entertainment of all sentient beings' minds, and the supernormal power of reaching all that is seen through intimacy.

Sitting, one sees countless lands in the ten directions, pervading all the Buddha-realms. Following their customs, one manifests their forms, and the body pervades all sentient beings in the ten directions, expounding the Dharma for them, enabling them to attain understanding and give rise to the intention for the great path.
This is the son of a great clan!
The spiritual powers practiced by the bodhisattvas are pure.
The Buddha told the son of a great clan:
The bodhisattvas' wisdom eye is endowed with the purity of the heavenly eye.
As for the heavenly eye, abiding in spiritual consciousness, it is also unattached, and thus one attains the fundamental purity of the heavenly ear.
Abiding without obstruction, one then immediately knows the thoughts of sentient beings, all penetrating through, and completely knows the past and future locations, all able to testify to them.
Abiding without action, all the defilements and the actions of birth and death are exhausted, and one then purifies the spiritual powers and thoroughly penetrates the supernormal knowledges.
What is called the supernormal knowledges is the gate of the holy wisdom of exhausting the defilements.
The bodhisattvas enjoy themselves with these five supernormal knowledges, but their minds do not abide in the wisdom of exhausting the defilements.
The Buddha told the son of a great clan:

It is like a city a hundred thousand yojanas away from a village. The road is long and dangerous, with many difficulties and obstacles, and bandits and robbers lurk in the dense and narrow passages, where lions, tigers, and wolves prey on each other.
If one can leave this road and reach that country, and enter the great city, one will be free from all suffering and have immeasurable peace and security.

At that time, there was a person who heard that the city had abundant blessings, merits, and happiness, and that its fame spread far. This person had only one son, whom he loved dearly and thought of constantly, never tiring of looking at him. Hearing the name of that country, he left his son and went there, exerting himself with diligence and enduring all the hardships and difficulties, day and night without slacking off, until he found shade and rest. Having mastered the six arts and armed with the five weapons, he was able to cross [the dangers].
When he reached the city gate, he stayed on top of the gate, and then proceeded further to the second gate, opened the city gate, and stood alone. He then recalled:
'My only son is not able to come with me.
Because of the affection for his son, he did not enter the great city, but returned to fetch his son and went together to the Land of Joy.
The Buddha told the son of a great clan:

The Bodhisattva, thus wearing the armor of the utmost, with great diligence and firm determination, manifested the great path through sincere effort, purified the mind's actions and the conduct of purity, ended the defilements, aroused the mind of great compassion, taught and transformed sentient beings, and with wisdom ended birth and death, attaining the end of the defilements and ultimate accomplishment.
Out of pity for sentient beings and wanting to save and protect them, he then returned and manifested the stage of ordinary beings.
The Buddha told the son of a great clan:
The city is a metaphor for the lofty holy wisdom of one whose defilements have already ended.

Traveling a long distance of hundreds of thousands of yojanas through difficulties and dangers refers to wandering through immeasurable births and deaths and various difficulties, saving and liberating sentient beings without being constrained by them.
Bandits, tigers, and wolves refer to the difficulties of the various demons, wrong views, and non-dharmas.
